是什么

"Moona Sayang Kak Pekora" meant basically "Moona Loves Pekora Nee-san". (Yep, it's the word above it)

There is no Senpai in Indonesian vocabulary (afaik none in English either)

"kak" also can be "senpai"

For Malay language(Indonesian, Malaysia, Brunei, Singapore)... 
Kakak = "big sister/brother" and can also be "senpai"
@UCbpeqMBJlmKuVos4lKyRKgA indeed, but it's basically has loose meaning that doesn't spefically used in Senpai-Kouhai relationship.
@DBT Adik in filipino has a totally different meaning
@DBT yep.. it's actually for family relations but 'kak'  can also used to address someone older than you too
@Afrizal Aminuddin imagine if "punten kak, gofood" in japanese will be "sumimasen senpai, gofood" jadi lucu 😂
In indonesian using kak to not related is for formal to elder or senior.. well in my work i use "bang" for my senior "bang = senpai for male"
It depends on the context

@DBT This holds true in other SEA languages esp in Filipino.

We have 'ate' to address a female senpai/older sister and we have 'kuya' to address a male senpai/older brother. But we have no honorifics for kouhais, we just call them by their first names.
Still senpai not become neechan,moona bisa aja nulis makasih senior pekora tapi terlalu kaku ya bener pake kak sama aja maknanya ke senpai
Thank you for the explanation
Thanks for the translation! Btw, Senpai is 'Senior' in english!
Menit berapa bg

@Kaysan 23 Yeah, but i rarely heard anyone address someone using senior directly by name, i only heard it as 3rd person speech.

But context wise "Senior Pekora" is indeed correct.
